<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module2_mcq_q33')" data-correct-answer="C">
<strong style="display: block;">
Which of the following statements best describes the behavior of the standard deviation (volatility) of a stock’s returns over time?
</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q33" value="A"> A. Standard deviation is constant over time, so past volatility perfectly predicts future volatility.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q33" value="B"> B. Volatility only changes when the firm’s capital structure changes significantly.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q33" value="C"> C. Volatility is time-varying: it tends to cluster in periods of market stress or crisis, rising sharply and then gradually declining.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q33" value="D"> D. Volatility reflects only idiosyncratic shocks, not market-wide conditions.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q33" value="E"> E. Standard deviation is irrelevant for risk measurement because it cannot change over time.</label><br>
</form>
<div id="feedback-module2_mcq_q33" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: C. Stock volatility is not constant — it is **time-varying**.  
Periods of market stress (e.g., crises) often show volatility spikes, followed by gradual normalization.  
This property is known as **volatility clustering**, and it is central to risk modeling in finance (e.g., ARCH/GARCH models).
</div>
